awd_titl_txt: Experimental Study of Biomimetic Antifreeze Polymers for Improved Durability of Cementitious Binders
awd_abstract_narration:
Ice is one of the few substances on Earth that expands when it freezes. Consequently, this expansion is destructive to porous materials, like concrete that are exposed to water and experienced freeze-thaw cycling. Conventional methods used to counter freeze-thaw deterioration in cement-based materials include entraining ~5-10% air (by volume), which reduces bulk mechanical properties, or applying deicing salts on the surface, which exacerbates chloride-induced corrosion of steel reinforcement. For more than 70 years, these methods have remained virtually unchanged. Inspired by nature, this work seeks to design and synthesize biomimetic antifreeze polymers (BAPs) that explicitly mimic the activity, function, and structure of antifreeze proteins (AFPs) naturally found in plants, insects, and bacteria and assess their suitability as an admixture biotechnology for cement-based materials. The research activities will enhance the long-term durability of cement-based materials and promote the sustainability and resilience of civil infrastructure. As part of this effort, the project team will engage local and global audiences via a videotaped seminar series on biomimetic architecture and living buildings in collaboration with Boulder Biomimicry, local biomimicry experts, and Women in Science and Engineering (WiSE) student organization at the University of Colorado Boulder.

     Using natural AFPs as a biological template, this work will first determine an ideal biomolecular model by studying the thermal hysteresis behaviors of recombinant AFPs in ionic media with a focus on synthetic, highly alkaline, ordinary portland cement and alkali-activated cement concrete pore solutions. BAPs will be synthesized using common biopolymers (i.e., PLGA) with modified moieties to explicitly mimic the ice-binding and ice-structuring behavior of native AFPs. The ice-binding and ice-structuring mechanisms of natural AFPs and synthetic BAPs will be investigated, in addition to their longevity, survivability, and efficacy in hardened cement paste and in concrete. This work will provide new knowledge on ice crystallization inhibition behavior of AFPs and synthetic BAPs in highly alkaline environments, which represents a significant departure from current BAP technologies that are being tested for biologically relevant applications. In addition, this work advances state-of-the-art antifreeze polymer technologies by designing BAPs that not only imitate the thermal hysteresis activity of native AFPs, but also explicitly mimic their functional (ice-binding) and structural (ice-structuring) mechanisms. Successful mimicking of these mechanisms will lead to a suite of disruptive admixture biotechnologies to conventional freeze-thaw durability approaches for cementitious materials.

por.por_cntn:
Ice is one of the few substances on Earth that expands when it freezes. Consequently, this expansion is destructive to porous materials, like concrete, that are exposed to water and experienced freeze-thaw cycling. Conventional methods used to counter freeze-thaw deterioration in cement-based materials include entraining ~5-10% air by volume. Despite its effectiveness at mitigating freeze-thaw damage in cement-based materials, air entrainment is difficult to control in the field. Air entrainment also has multiple technical drawbacks, including a reduction in bulk mechanical properties and an increase in permeability, which can exacerbate other durability concerns (e.g., chloride-induced corrosion). For more than 70 years, however, air entrainment has remained the primary approach to ensure the freeze-thaw durability of concrete. 

Inspired by nature, this project designed, synthesized, and tested biomimetic antifreeze polymers that explicitly mimic the activity, function, and structure of antifreeze proteins and antifreeze glycoproteins naturally found in plants, insects, and bacteria and assessed their suitability as an alternative frost-resistant strategy for cement-based materials. In the first phase of this research, two antifreeze proteins were isolated and tested for ice recrystallization inhibition (IRI) activity in high-pH solutions that mimicked the chemical environment of concrete. The results showed that native antifreeze proteins retain some IRI activity in high-pH solutions, despite partial denaturation and misfolding. In the second phase of this research, synthetic molecules based on the amino acid threonine were found to best mimicked the functionality and IRI activity of native antifreeze proteins. Using poly(threonine) as a molecular model, the synthetic polymer pHPMA was designed, synthesized, and tested to showed that it can mitigate ice crystal growth at concentrations similar to native IBPs in high-pH solutions. In a parallel workstream, two commercially available IRI-active biomimetic antifreeze polymers, namely PVA and PEG-PVA, were selected for testing in cement paste and concrete. When used as an additive to cement paste, both molecules mitigated freeze-thaw damage in cement paste without entraining air. Through differential scanning calorimetry measurements, it was confirmed that the inclusion of these molecules resulted in the formation of lower quantities of ice during freezing events, indicating that frost resistance was due, in part, to the ice interaction characteristics of the biomimetic polymers. Additional experimental testing further substantiated that the addition of biomimetic PEG-PVA mitigated freeze-thaw damage in portland cement concrete samples—without entraining air. 

Taken together, the results from this work demonstrated that an alternative, bioinspired mechanism (i.e., IRI activity) can be leveraged to prevent damage from ice crystal growth in cementitious materials. The scientific findings from these research activities underpin continued research and development of a new generation of bioinspired chemical admixtures that will ultimately enhance the long-term durability of cement-based materials and promote the sustainability and resilience of civil infrastructure. In addition, the results from this work can be used to inform new innovations and other frost-prevention applications in fields such as the cryopreservation of organs and tissues, aviation, and agriculture. This work supported the education and training of one female postdoctoral scholar, four doctoral students, and four undergraduate student researchers, including three female graduate and undergraduate students. These next-generation thought leaders will continue to advance the research and development of novel cement chemistries that address the sustainability and long-term durability of civil infrastructure and related fields.
